Description: A hollow terracotta figure of a Sothic dog standing to right on a low curved flat-fronted plinth, its head turned to the front. It is a spitz-type hound, but leaner than most. Its tail is tightly curled, and it wears a bell round its neck and bands round its middle. Plain back, with circular vent. Two-piece mould. Micaceous red-brown Nile silt, burnt dark brown over large areas. Traces of a white dressing overall, with minute surviving touches of pink paint.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Greville J. Chester. Roman, first or second century AD. This is a spitz-type hound, but leaner than most, and is more like those shown on coins, etc., with Isis riding (for example, Poole 1892: pl. xvi:1121 and 1339, of Antoninus Pius and Faustina II). Comparanda: Near: Hadjisavvas 2000: 667, fig. 3, from Dekelia, Cyprus; Michałowski et al. 1938: pl. xxxviii:14, from Edfu, second century AD context; Szyma´nska 2005: no. 262, from Athribis, dated second to first century BC.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3710)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 1991 8 Jan-24 Mar, Birmingham Museum and City Art Gallery, Man’s Best Friend
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
